abstract.p: William C Rhoden Sports of The Times column discusses recent play of New York Jets rookie receiver Laveranues Coles (M)

block.p: THIS fall has been good to the Jets.

THIS fall has been good to the Jets.
They played hard, and executed a solid game plan that exploited their strengths and hid their flaws. Under their first-year coach, Al Groh, the Jets won six of their first seven games.

They became masters of the comeback victory. The Jets trailed Green Bay, 16-13, in the fourth quarter and won, 20-16. They trailed New England, 19-7, in the fourth quarter and won 20-19. They trailed Tampa Bay, 17-6, in the third quarter and won, 21-17. Last Monday, the Jets trailed Miami, 30-7, in the third quarter and wound up winning, 40-37, in overtime.
Yesterday the Jets fell behind a desperate Bills team but, after tying the score, ran out of comebacks.
Was this a blip or an omen?

As the Jets approach the heart of their season -- a home game against Denver, two games with Indianapolis, a rematch at Miami and a game at Oakland over the next six weeks -- Groh has a decision to make.
The Jets' flaws are apparent; it's only a matter of time before teams with enough experience to exploit the weaknesses actually will.
The Jets are getting diminished production from the wide receivers. Their leading receivers are running backs. Wayne Chrebet has 33 catches for the season; Dedric Ward has 22.

In the their first seven games, the Jets got by on a passing game consisting of short shots to running backs and possession passes to wide receivers. On Sunday, Chrebet had 6 receptions for 69 yards, Curtis Martin 6 for 31 yards, Richie Anderson 6 for 24 yards.
So Laveranues Coles's numbers jump out at you; the 22-year-old rookie had 5 receptions for 131 yards. Ward's numbers jump out, too; the fourth-year veteran had 3 receptions for 25 yards.
Coles will soon be forcing Groh to make a decision. Start Coles and bring Ward off the bench in his old third-receiver role, or maintain the status quo.
Groh confined his comments and compliments about Coles to yesterday's game.
''He did a nice job for us today,'' Groh said, adding cryptically, ''Hopefully, this is a little window for the future.''
Which future? The immediate future with Broncos, Colts and Raiders in it, or the long-term future of a new season?
At the very least, Coles has gone from the periphery to the center of Vinny Testaverde's radar.
After the game, Coles talked about how gratified he was that Testaverde had pulled him aside and told him what he wanted from him.

''Just told me he wanted me in the defense's face, where wanted me to run routes,'' Coles said. ''Just the idea he's looking at me makes me feel good; makes me not want him to lose confidence in me. When your quarterback puts that kind of trust in you, you don't want to let him down.''

For a crucial fourth-quarter stretch, the rookie was Testaverde's go-to receiver. First, Testaverde hit Coles for a 19-yard gain. On first-and-10 at the Jets' 45, Testaverde hit Coles for a 21-yard gain. Then on third-and-12, Testaverde hit Coles for 14 yards. Four plays later, the Jets kicked a 36-yard field goal to tie the score, 20-20.
''He was on the periphery of our game plan,'' said Bills safety Henry Jones, who intercepted a pass intended for Chrebet.

Jones added: ''They weren't really going to him at first; then he started getting open. He looked good on film. He's got speed, good quickness, he's a good runner after he catches the ball. He's someone to contend with. He's special.''
Now, after quietly making his presence known, opposing defenses are beginning to look at Coles. A national audience will, too.
Coles wishes his past would go away, but it won't. As his stature grows, his story becomes more compelling.

Briefly, Coles and his Florida State teammate Peter Warrick were arrested last year after they purchased clothes at a Dillard's department store and were charged only a fraction of the price by a saleswoman who had undercharged Warrick several times before. Warrick was suspended for one game and Coles was thrown off the team because he had violated school probation for a variety of other legal and academic problems.
Warrick was a first-round pick last April, while Coles, who had been projected as a first-round pick, was drafted in the third round. He could be the greatest bargain in the draft.
The Jets and Groh, who said Coles was ''hungry for another chance,'' gave him a second opportunity. Coles is making the most of it.

Warrick has 21 catches for 255 yards and 2 touchdowns with Cincinnati; Coles has 18 receptions for 291 yards and a touchdown. Last Monday, Coles scored his first National Football League touchdown when he snatched a pass away from the veteran Sam Madison in the end zone on a 30-yard play. Yesterday against Buffalo, he raced behind the defense for a 63-yard reception.
The good news for Coles is that he has gotten Testaverde's attention; the challenging news is that Coles has gotten the defense's attention, too.
''We didn't really have a game plan for him coming into the game,'' said Ted Cottrell, the Bills' defensive coordinator. ''We didn't really know a lot about him. We know about him now.''
Groh knows, too, and soon he'll have a decision to make.
